name: Priest's Pack
entries: A Priest's Pack contains the following items: {@item Backpack|XPHB}, {@item Blanket|XPHB}, {@item Holy Water|XPHB}, {@item Lamp|XPHB}, 7 days of {@item Rations|XPHB}, {@item Robe|XPHB}, and {@item Tinderbox|XPHB}.

name: Primal Amulet
entries: This beaded jade necklace bears an ancient symbol of the River Heralds. When worn, the primal amulet allows its wearer to cast {@spell speak with animals}, {@spell locate object}, and {@spell pass without trace}. Once the amulet has been used to cast a spell, it can't be used to cast that spell again until the next dawn.

entries: This well enhances the colors of the city of Harmony and invigorates the population. When the well is at full power, all good-aligned creatures that see the colors experience feelings of happiness and have advantage on all Charisma checks.

name: Propeller Helm
entries: While worn, the helm allows its wearer to use an action to cast the {@spell levitate} spell, requiring no components. The helm's propeller spins and whirs loudly until the spell ends. Each time the spell ends, there is a {@chance 50} chance that the helm loses its magic and becomes nonmagical.
attunementText: requires attunement by a small humanoid

name: Prosthetic Limb
entries: This magic item replaces a lost limb—a hand, an arm, a foot, a leg, or a similar body part. While the prosthetic is attached, it functions identically to the part it replaces. You can detach or reattach it as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action, and it can't be removed against your will while you are alive.

name: Pyremaul (Awakened)

entries.name: Awakened
entries: When Pyremaul reaches an awakened state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +2.
The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to {@damage 2d6}.

As an action, you can slam Pyremaul into the ground to cast the {@spell burning hands} spell at 2nd level (save {@dc 15}). You can't use this property again until you finish a {@quickref resting|PHB|2|0|short or long rest}.
Whenever you score a critical hit with this weapon, the target must succeed on a {@dc 15} Strength {@quickref saving throws|PHB|2|1|saving throw} or be knocked {@condition prone}.

item_description: The pyremaul (awakened) smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
entries: The pyremaul (awakened) smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
flavor: Pyremaul (Awakened) looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with well-worn grips and a smell of oil that speaks of use.

name: Pyremaul (Dormant)
entries: Made for wandering heroes, the pyremaul (dormant) nicks and oil stains speak to many a fray.
item_description: Made for wandering heroes, the pyremaul (dormant) nicks and oil stains speak to many a fray.
flavor: Pyremaul (Dormant) is a saint-forged melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show nicks and polish; up close there’s a scent of old leather and a low hum when drawn.

name: Pyremaul (Exalted)

entries.name: Exalted
entries: When Pyremaul reaches an exalted state, you gain the following benefits:

items: The weapon's bonus to attack rolls increases to +3.
The extra fire damage dealt by the weapon increases to {@damage 3d6}.
When you cast {@spell burning hands} with the weapon, you do so at 3rd level and the save DC increases to 17.

When you score a critical hit with this weapon, the {@quickref saving throws|PHB|2|1|saving throw} to avoid being knocked {@condition prone} increases to 17. You also roll an extra {@damage 3d6} fire damage when determining the extra damage for the critical hit.

When you kill a creature with an attack using this weapon, you can take {@damage 10d10} fire damage and immolate the creature's corpse. This damage can't be reduced in any way, and you die if this damage reduces you to 0 hit points. The immolated creature and everything it is wearing and carrying, except magic items, are reduced to a pile of ash. The creature can be restored to life only by means of a {@spell true resurrection} or a {@spell wish} spell. You can't use this property of the maul again until 7 days have passed.

item_description: The pyremaul (exalted) stows neatly among bedrolls and rations.
entries: The pyremaul (exalted) stows neatly among bedrolls and rations.
flavor: Pyremaul (Exalted) looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with tool-marks and a smell of oil that speaks of use.

name: Quaal's Feather Token, Anchor
entries: This object looks like a feather.

You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to touch the token to a boat or ship. For the next 24 hours, the vessel can't be moved by any means. Touching the token to the vessel again ends the effect. When the effect ends, the token disappears.
item_description: This object looks like a feather.
flavor: Quaal's Feather Token, Anchor looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with careful repairs and a dust of old vaults that speaks of use.

name: Quaal's Feather Token, Bird
entries: This object looks like a feather.

You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to toss the token 5 feet into the air. The token disappears and an enormous, multicolored bird takes its place. The bird has the statistics of a {@creature Roc|XMM}, but it can't attack. It obeys your simple commands and can carry up to 500 pounds while flying at its maximum speed (16 miles per hour for a maximum of 144 miles per day, with a 1-hour rest for every 3 hours of flying) or 1,000 pounds at half that speed. The bird disappears after flying its maximum distance for a day or if it drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. You can dismiss the bird as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action.
item_description: This object looks like a feather.
flavor: Quaal's Feather Token, Bird looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with careful repairs and a scent of old leather that speaks of use.

name: Quaal's Feather Token, Fan
entries: This object looks like a feather.

If you are on a boat or ship, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to toss the token up to 10 feet in the air. The token disappears, and a giant flapping fan takes its place. The fan floats and creates a strong wind. This wind can fill the sails of one ship, increasing its speed by 5 miles per hour for 8 hours. You can dismiss the fan as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action.
item_description: This object looks like a feather.
flavor: Quaal's Feather Token, Fan looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with careful repairs and a tang of metal that speaks of use.

name: Quaal's Feather Token, Swan Boat
entries: This object looks like a feather.

You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to touch the token to a body of water at least 60 feet in diameter. The token disappears, and a 50-foot-long, 20-foot-wide boat shaped like a swan takes its place. The boat is self-propelled and moves across water at a speed of 6 miles per hour. You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action while on the boat to command it to move or to turn up to 90 degrees. The boat remains for 24 hours and then disappears. You can dismiss the boat as a {@action Magic|XPHB} action.
item_description: This object looks like a feather.
flavor: Quaal's Feather Token, Swan Boat looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with careful repairs and a scent of old leather that speaks of use.

name: Quaal's Feather Token, Tree
entries: This object looks like a feather.

You must be outdoors to use this token. You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to touch it to an unoccupied space on the ground. The token disappears, and in its place a nonmagical oak tree springs into existence. The tree is 60 feet tall and has a 5-foot-diameter trunk, and its branches at the top spread out in a 20-foot radius.
item_description: This object looks like a feather.
flavor: Quaal's Feather Token, Tree looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with tool-marks and a hint of ozone that speaks of use.

name: Quaal's Feather Token, Whip
entries: A common sight among adventurers, the quaal's feather token, whip nicks and oil stains speak to many a fray.
item_description: A common sight among adventurers, the quaal's feather token, whip nicks and oil stains speak to many a fray.
flavor: Quaal's Feather Token, Whip looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with tool-marks and a hint of ozone that speaks of use.

entries.caption: Quandrix Trinkets
rows: A small succulent in a dodecahedral clay pot
A blue knit hat that looks a bit like a bottle folding in on itself
A model hypercube carved from green crystal, showcasing the fourth dimension
A crumpled test on the theory of gravity manipulation, with a failing grade on the front and the name of a famous Quandrix professor
A blue tetrahedron that, when tapped twice, projects a recording of an old mathematics lecture
A round bread roll cut so that someone could spread butter on both halves without ever lifting the knife

name: Quiver
entries: A Quiver holds up to 20 Arrows.
item_description: A Quiver holds up to 20 Arrows.
flavor: Quiver is plain field kit: straps tight, stitching true, and the dust of old vaults that clings to road-beaten gear.

name: Quiver of Ehlonna
entries: Each of the quiver's three compartments connects to an extradimensional space that allows the quiver to hold numerous items while never weighing more than 2 pounds. The shortest compartment can hold up to 60 {@item Arrow|XPHB|Arrows}, {@item Bolt|XPHB|Bolts}, or similar objects. The midsize compartment holds up to 18 {@item Javelin|XPHB|Javelins} or similar objects. The longest compartment holds up to 6 long objects, such as bows, {@item Quarterstaff|XPHB|Quarterstaff's}, or {@item Spear|XPHB|Spears}.
You can draw any item the quiver contains as if doing so from a regular quiver or scabbard.
item_description: Each of the quiver's three compartments connects to an extradimensional space that allows the quiver to hold numerous items while never weighing more than 2 pounds. The shortest compartment can hold up to 60 {@item Arrow|XPHB|Arrows}, {@item Bolt|XPHB|Bolts}, or similar objects. name: Rain Catcher
entries: A rain catcher is a simple contraption consisting of a 5-foot-square leather tarp and a wooden frame with legs. When the tarp is stretched across the wooden frame, it forms a basin that can catch 2 gallons of drinking water per inch of rainfall and hold up to 8 gallons. The tarp and wooden frame fold up for easy transport.

The tarp and wooden frame fold up for easy transport.

name: Rakdos Guild Signet
entries: Rumor runs that the rakdos guild signet remembers every hand that held it.
item_description: Rumor runs that the rakdos guild signet remembers every hand that held it.
flavor: Rakdos Guild Signet bears a curious aura—cool to the touch, edges crisp, and a low hum of latent sorcery beneath the tang of metal.

name: Rakdos Keyrune
reqAttune: by a member of the Rakdos guild
entries: This dark granite keyrune is marbled with scarlet veins and carved with the leering visage of a mischievous demon. When activated, it transforms into a {@creature cackler|GGR} for up to 1 hour.

When you use an action to speak the item's command word and place the keyrune on the ground in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you, the keyrune transforms into a {@creature cackler|GGR}. If there isn't enough space for the creature, the keyrune doesn't transform.

The creature is friendly to you, your companions, and other members of your guild (unless those guild members are hostile to you). It understands your languages and obeys your spoken commands. If you issue no commands, the creature takes the {@action Dodge} action and moves to avoid danger.

At the end of the duration, the creature reverts to its keyrune form. It reverts early if it drops to 0 hit points or if you use an action to speak the command word again while touching it. When the creature reverts to its keyrune form, it can't transform again until 36 hours have passed.
attunementText: requires attunement by a member of the Rakdos guild
item_description: This dark granite keyrune is marbled with scarlet veins and carved with the leering visage of a mischievous demon. When activated, it transforms into a {@creature cackler|GGR} for up to 1 hour.
flavor: Rakdos Keyrune looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with scuffs at the edges and a smell of oil that speaks of use.

name: Rations

name: Red Wizard Blade
entries: Forged by Red Wizards using a secret process known only to them, this grim steel dagger draws its power from the Negative Plane. When you hit a creature with a melee attack using this magic dagger, the target takes an extra {@damage 3d12} necrotic damage.

A creature reduced to 0 hit points by this weapon dies and can't be raised from the dead except by a deity or by a creature using a {@item tablet of reawakening|HAT-LMI} to cast the {@spell true resurrection} spell.
item_description: Forged by Red Wizards using a secret process known only to them, this grim steel dagger draws its power from the Negative Plane. When you hit a creature with a melee attack using this magic dagger, the target takes an extra {@damage 3d12} necrotic damage.
flavor: Red Wizard Blade is a legend-haunted melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show well-worn grips; up close there’s a whiff of parchment and a soft chime when drawn.

name: Reincarnation Dust
entries: When this small pouch of purple dust is sprinkled on a dead humanoid or a piece of a dead humanoid, the dust is absorbed by the remains. If willing, the dead creature returns to life with a new body as if the {@spell reincarnate} spell had been cast on the remains.
item_description: When this small pouch of purple dust is sprinkled on a dead humanoid or a piece of a dead humanoid, the dust is absorbed by the remains. If willing, the dead creature returns to life with a new body as if the {@spell reincarnate} spell had been cast on the remains.
flavor: Reincarnation Dust looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with scuffs at the edges and a smell of oil that speaks of use.

name: Residuum
entries: The sheer amount of leftover arcane power within the {@item whitestone|TDCSR} of the mountains is incredibly receptive to enchantment. Magic items that incorporate at least an ounce of {@item whitestone|TDCSR} into their construction require only one-quarter the creation time of other magic items. Some alchemists in {@book Emon|TDCSR|3|Emon, the City of Fellowship} have discovered that dissolving {@item whitestone|TDCSR} with specific acids can leave behind pure residuum, which can substitute for expensive spell components when such materials are not readily available.

If a spell has a component cost that consumes the component, its caster can substitute the required component for an amount of residuum of an equal value. One pound of pure residuum is worth approximately 500 gp in most markets, though it becomes extremely expensive and difficult to find outside of {@book Emon|TDCSR|3|Emon, the City of Fellowship} or the city of {@book Whitestone|TDCSR|3|Whitestone} itself.

Residuum can also be heated and blown into glass, forming a shimmering, greenish surface. Residuum slates or orbs can be used in stationary enchanting tables. Archmages willing to pay exorbitant rates—easily 20,000 gp or more—may acquire an {@item Residuum enchanting slate|TDCSR|enchanting slate} that can be used to expedite the creation of all magic items. Using such a table allows anyone crafting a magic item to do so in one-quarter of the usual time.
item_description: The sheer amount of leftover arcane power within the {@item whitestone|TDCSR} of the mountains is incredibly receptive to enchantment. Magic items that incorporate at least an ounce of {@item whitestone|TDCSR} into their construction require only one-quarter the creation time of other magic items. Some alchemists in {@book Emon|TDCSR|3|Emon, the City of Fellowship} have discovered that dissolving {@item whitestone|TDCSR} with specific acids can leave behind pure residuum, which can substitute for expensive spell components when such materials are not readily available.
flavor: Residuum is standard stock—sealed, weighed, and marked for barter; the scent of old leather hints at its origin.

name: Ring of Djinni Summoning
entries: While wearing this ring, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to summon a particular {@creature Djinni|XMM} from the Elemental Plane of Air. The djinni appears in an unoccupied space you choose within 120 feet of yourself. It remains as long as you maintain {@status Concentration|XPHB}, to a maximum of 1 hour, or until it drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}.

While summoned, the djinni is {@variantrule Friendly [Attitude]|XPHB|Friendly} to you and your allies, and it obeys your commands. If you fail to command it, the djinni defends itself against attackers but takes no other actions.
After the djinni departs, it can't be summoned again for 24 hours, and the ring becomes nonmagical if the djinni dies.
Rings of Djinni Summoning are often created by the djinn they summon and given to mortals as gifts of friendship or tokens of esteem.

name: Ring of Mind Shielding
entries: While wearing this ring, you are immune to magic that allows other creatures to read your thoughts, determine whether you are lying, know your alignment, or know your creature type. Creatures can telepathically communicate with you only if you allow it.

You can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to cause the ring to become imperceptible until you take another {@action Magic|XPHB} action to make it perceptible, until you remove the ring, or until you die.

If you die while wearing the ring, your soul enters it, unless it already houses a soul. You can remain in the ring or depart for the afterlife. As long as your soul is in the ring, you can telepathically communicate with any creature wearing it. A wearer can't prevent this telepathic communication.

name: Ring of the Copycat
entries: You gain the ability to channel energy from allies to cast spells, even if you normally can't. When an ally within 60 feet of you casts a spell that you normally can't cast and that requires 10 gp or fewer in material components, you may use a reaction to cast that spell. When cast in this way, the spell is cast using your ally's spellcasting ability, spell save DC, and spell attack bonus, as needed. You decide this cloned spell's target, as specified in the spell's description, and the spell originates from you. After you use this ability, your ally can't cast this spell again until they finish a long rest.

name: Rod
item_description: Inscribed in tidy hands, the rod carries power for those who can read it.
entries: Inscribed in tidy hands, the rod carries power for those who can read it.
flavor: Rod carries crisp sigils and the dryness of vellum; a quiet creak rises when traced, and a scent of old leather clings to the arcane ink.

name: Rod of Absorption
entries: While holding this rod, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to absorb a spell that is targeting only you and doesn't create an area of effect. The absorbed spell's effect is canceled, and the spell's energy—not the spell itself—is stored in the rod. The energy has the same level as the spell when it was cast. A canceled spell dissipates with no effect, and any resources used to cast it are wasted. The rod can absorb and store up to 50 levels of energy over the course of its existence. Once the rod absorbs 50 levels of energy, it can't absorb more. If you are targeted by a spell that the rod can't store, the rod has no effect on that spell.
When you become attuned to the rod, you know how many levels of energy the rod has absorbed over the course of its existence and how many levels of spell energy it currently has stored.

If you are a spellcaster holding the rod, you can convert energy stored in it into spell slots to cast spells you have prepared or know. You can create spell slots only of a level equal to or lower than your own spell slots, up to a maximum of level 5. You use the stored levels in place of your slots but otherwise cast the spell as normal. For example, you can use 3 levels stored in the rod as a level 3 spell slot.
A newly found rod typically has {@dice 1d10} levels of spell energy stored in it. A rod that can no longer absorb spell energy and has no energy remaining becomes nonmagical.
item_description: While holding this rod, you can take a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB} to absorb a spell that is targeting only you and doesn't create an area of effect. The absorbed spell's effect is canceled, and the spell's energy—not the spell itself—is stored in the rod. The energy has the same level as the spell when it was cast. A canceled spell dissipates with no effect, and any resources used to cast it are wasted. The rod can absorb and store up to 50 levels of energy over the course of its existence. Once the rod absorbs 50 levels of energy, it can't absorb more. If you are targeted by a spell that the rod can't store, the rod has no effect on that spell.
flavor: Rod of Absorption is a exceptional length of fine wood—balanced like a conductor’s baton, warm in the palm with a low hum of stored power.

name: Rod of Hellish Flames
entries: Glowing cinders orbit the flanged head of this black iron rod.
This rod can be used as an arcane focus. While holding this rod, you gain the following benefits:

items.name: Hellish Resistance
entries: You have resistance to fire and necrotic damage.

items.name: Searing Rebuke
entries: You can cast the {@spell Hellish Rebuke} spell as a 4th-level spell (save {@dc 16}) from the rod. Once you use the rod to cast the spell, the rod can't cast the spell again until the next dawn.

items.name: Surge of Brimstone
entries: Whenever you cast a spell that deals fire or necrotic damage, you can use the rod to deal the maximum damage instead of rolling. Once this property is used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.

item_description: Glowing cinders orbit the flanged head of this black iron rod.
flavor: Rod of Hellish Flames is a masterwork length of fine wood—balanced like a conductor’s baton, warm in the palm with a quiet creak of stored power.

name: Rod of Mercurial Form
entries: This humble steel rod is engraved with tiny symbols representing different weapons, as well as the monogram "T.D." A creature holding this rod can speak the name of any simple or martial weapon aloud as a bonus action, causing the rod to transform into an ordinary weapon of that type. When in the form of a ranged weapon, this rod magically creates its own ammunition, which disappears after a ranged attack hits or misses.

name: Rod of Security
entries: While holding this rod, you can take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to activate it. The rod then instantly transports you and up to 199 other willing creatures you can see to a demiplane. You choose the form the demiplane takes. It could be a tranquil garden, a cheery tavern, an immense palace, a tropical island, a fantastic carnival, or whatever else you can imagine. Regardless of its nature, the demiplane contains enough water and food to sustain its visitors, and the demiplane's environment can't harm its occupants. Everything else that can be interacted with there can exist only there. For example, a flower picked from a garden there disappears if it is taken outside the demiplane.

For each hour spent in the demiplane, a visitor regains {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB} as if it had spent 1 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB|Hit Point} Die. Also, creatures don't age while there, although time passes normally. Visitors can remain there for up to 200 days divided by the number of creatures present (round down).

When the time runs out or you take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to end the effect, all visitors reappear in the location they occupied when you activated the rod or an unoccupied space nearest that location. Once used, this property can't be used again until 10 days have passed.

name: Rope of Mending
entries: You can cut this 50-foot coil of hempen rope into any number of smaller pieces, and then use an action to speak a command word and cause the pieces to knit back together. The pieces must be in contact with each other and not otherwise in use. A rope of mending is forever shortened if a section of it is lost or destroyed.

name: Rowboat
entries: Keelboats and rowboats are used on lakes and rivers, If going downstream, add the speed of the current (typically 3 miles per hour) to the speed of the vehicle. These vehicles can't be rowed against any significant current, but they can be pulled upstream by draft animals on the shores. A rowboat weighs 100 pounds, in case adventurers carry it over land.

name: Ruin's Wake (Awakened)

items.name: Awakened
entries: When the spear reaches an awakened state, it gains the following properties:

items: The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +2, and the extra piercing damage dealt by the weapon increases to {@damage 2d8}.

When you hurl the spear and speak a command word, it transforms into a bolt of lightning, forming a line 5 feet wide that extends out from you to a creature you can see within 120 feet of you. Each creature in the line, excluding you, must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw, taking {@damage 8d6} lightning damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. Ruin's Wake then returns to your hand. This property can't be used again until the next dawn.

item_description: The ruin's wake (awakened) rugged enough for damp caves and busy market streets.
entries: The ruin's wake (awakened) rugged enough for damp caves and busy market streets.

name: Ruin's Wake (Exalted)

items.name: Exalted
entries: When the spear reaches an exalted state, it gains the following properties:

items: The weapon's bonus to attack and damage rolls increases to +3.

While holding the spear, you can let out a battle cry as a bonus action. Each creature you choose within 30 feet of you gains advantage on attack rolls until the start of your next turn. This property can't be used again until the next dawn.

When you reduce a creature to 0 hit points with an attack from the spear, you can regain hit points equal to the damage you dealt with the attack. This property can't be used again until the next dawn.

name: Sage's Signet (Bear)
entries: This gilded ring bears a beautiful engraving and is imbued with powers of keen wisdom and foresight. While wearing this ring, you can use an action to cast the {@spell Augury} spell from the ring. Once you use the ring to cast the spell, the ring can't cast the spell again until the next dawn.

While wearing the Sage's Signet, you can cast the {@spell Enlarge/Reduce} and {@spell Polymorph} once each from the ring using your Intelligence as the spellcasting ability. Once you cast each spell from the ring, the ring can't cast the spell again until the next dawn.

flavor: Sage's Signet (Serpent) bears a finely balanced aura—cool to the touch, edges crisp, and a low hum of latent sorcery beneath the tang of metal.

name: Sage's Signet (Songbird)
entries: This gilded ring bears a beautiful engraving and is imbued with powers of keen wisdom and foresight. While wearing this ring, you can use an action to cast the {@spell Augury} spell from the ring. Once you use the ring to cast the spell, the ring can't cast the spell again until the next dawn.

While wearing the Sage's Signet, you can cast the {@spell Charm Person} and {@spell Hypnotic Pattern} once each from the ring using your Intelligence as the spellcasting ability. Once you cast each spell from the ring, the ring can't cast the spell again until the next dawn.

While wearing this ring, you can use an action to cast the {@spell Augury} spell from the ring. Once you use the ring to cast the spell, the ring can't cast the spell again until the next dawn.

While wearing the Sage's Signet, you can cast the {@spell Freedom of Movement} and {@spell Pass without Trace} once each from the ring using your Intelligence as the spellcasting ability. Once you cast each spell from the ring, the ring can't cast the spell again until the next dawn.

flavor: Sage's Signet (Wolf) bears a exceptional aura—cool to the touch, edges crisp, and a low hum of latent sorcery beneath the dust of old vaults.

name: Sailing Ship
item_description: The sailing ship bears the marks of long travel and rough weather.
entries: The sailing ship bears the marks of long travel and rough weather.
flavor: Sailing Ship bears workmanlike craftsmanship—rigging tidy, timbers sound, and the dust of old vaults of tar, rope, and long voyages.

name: Saint Markovia's Thighbone
entries: Favored by sellswords and town guards, the saint markovia's thighbone its weight and balance make it trustworthy in battle.
item_description: Favored by sellswords and town guards, the saint markovia's thighbone its weight and balance make it trustworthy in battle.
flavor: Saint Markovia's Thighbone is a finely balanced bone melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show nicks and polish; up close there’s a dust of old vaults and a dull thrum when drawn.

name: Salt
item_description: Traders haggle over salt by weight, jurying quality with a quick eye.
entries: Traders haggle over salt by weight, jurying quality with a quick eye.
flavor: Salt is standard stock—sealed, weighed, and marked for barter; the hint of ozone hints at its origin.

name: Sanctum Amulet
entries: A black opal pendant hangs at the base of this pearlescent chain. The sacred rune is inscribed on the back of the pendant.
While wearing this item, you have resistance to necrotic damage. Additionally, you can cast the {@spell spare the dying} cantrip using either an action or a bonus action.

entries.name: Invoking the Rune
entries: When a creature you can see within 60 feet of you is reduced to 0 hit points as a result of taking damage, you can use your reaction to invoke the item's rune, causing the pendant to flash with pale light. The creature then instead drops to 1 hit point.
Once the rune has been invoked, it can't be invoked again until the next dawn.

item_description: A black opal pendant hangs at the base of this pearlescent chain. The sacred rune is inscribed on the back of the pendant.
flavor: Sanctum Amulet (Amulet) bears a exceptional aura—cool to the touch, edges crisp, and a soft chime of latent sorcery beneath the hint of ozone.

name: Sapphire Buckler
entries: Sapphire Buckler is a suit of protective gear—scuffed at the edges from hard marches and roadside mends.
item_description: Sapphire Buckler is a suit of protective gear—scuffed at the edges from hard marches and roadside mends.
flavor: Sapphire Buckler is a masterwork wood-and-metal shield—face worn smooth by impacts, rim scarred, straps supple with hint of ozone.

name: Sardonyx
entries: A bands of red and white gemstone.
item_description: A bands of red and white gemstone.
flavor: Sardonyx is standard stock—sealed, weighed, and marked for barter; the dust of old vaults hints at its origin.

name: Sarlona Trinket
entries: The sarlona trinket the sort of thing one misses only when it’s gone.
item_description: The sarlona trinket the sort of thing one misses only when it’s gone.
flavor: Sarlona Trinket is serviceable field kit: straps tight, stitching true, and the smell of oil that clings to road-beaten gear.

name: Scale Mail
entries: This armor consists of a coat and leggings (and perhaps a separate skirt) of leather covered with overlapping pieces of metal, much like the scales of a fish. The suit includes gauntlets.
item_description: This armor consists of a coat and leggings (and perhaps a separate skirt) of leather covered with overlapping pieces of metal, much like the scales of a fish. The suit includes gauntlets.
flavor: Scale Mail is a workmanlike suit of metal and leather—buckles and rivets tight, plates and links bearing nicks and polish; it carries the scent of old leather of long marches.

name: Scarab of Protection
entries: The scarab of protection smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
item_description: The scarab of protection smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
flavor: Scarab of Protection looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with nicks and polish and a dust of old vaults that speaks of use.

name: Scholar's Pack
entries: A Scholar's Pack contains the following items: {@item Backpack|XPHB}, {@item Book|XPHB}, {@item Ink|XPHB}, {@item Ink Pen|XPHB}, {@item Lamp|XPHB}, 10 flasks of {@item Oil|XPHB}, 10 sheets of {@item Parchment|XPHB}, and {@item Tinderbox|XPHB}.
item_description: A Scholar's Pack contains the following items: {@item Backpack|XPHB}, {@item Book|XPHB}, {@item Ink|XPHB}, {@item Ink Pen|XPHB}, {@item Lamp|XPHB}, 10 flasks of {@item Oil|XPHB}, 10 sheets of {@item Parchment|XPHB}, and {@item Tinderbox|XPHB}.
flavor: Scholar's Pack is workmanlike field kit: straps tight, stitching true, and the scent of old leather that clings to road-beaten gear.

name: Scimitar
item_description: A common sight among adventurers, the scimitar its edge holds well with a bit of care and whetstone.
entries: A common sight among adventurers, the scimitar its edge holds well with a bit of care and whetstone.
flavor: Scimitar is a workmanlike melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show well-worn grips; up close there’s a smell of oil and a quiet creak when drawn.

name: Scimitar of Speed
entries: A staple of the gear-chest, the scimitar of speed a straightforward design that trades flourish for grit.
item_description: A staple of the gear-chest, the scimitar of speed a straightforward design that trades flourish for grit.
flavor: Scimitar of Speed is a exceptional melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show well-worn grips; up close there’s a scent of old leather and a soft chime when drawn.

name: Scissors of Shadow Snipping
reqAttune: by a fey or a spellcaster
entries: The scissors of shadow snipping smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
attunementText: requires attunement by a fey or a spellcaster
item_description: The scissors of shadow snipping smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
flavor: Scissors of Shadow Snipping looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with scuffs at the edges and a dust of old vaults that speaks of use.

name: Scorpion Armor
entries: Scorpion Armor is a suit of protective gear—worn over gambeson with straps that creak when buckled.
item_description: Scorpion Armor is a suit of protective gear—worn over gambeson with straps that creak when buckled.
flavor: Scorpion Armor is a prized suit of metal and leather—buckles and rivets tight, plates and links bearing well-worn grips; it carries the hint of ozone of long marches.

name: Scorpion Ship
entries: Scorpion ships are archaic metal warships that have never lost their popularity, largely because of their versatility. Articulated legs enable a scorpion ship to land safely on the ground and move across a solid surface at a walking speed of 30 feet. The ship can't float on water, however. A ballista is mounted on the top deck, and a mangonel is perched on the end of the tail. The ship's two claws are relatively inefficient in combat, but a claw that grabs a creature can quickly take it out of action.
item_description: Scorpion ships are archaic metal warships that have never lost their popularity, largely because of their versatility. Articulated legs enable a scorpion ship to land safely on the ground and move across a solid surface at a walking speed of 30 feet. The ship can't float on water, however. A ballista is mounted on the top deck, and a mangonel is perched on the end of the tail. The ship's two claws are relatively inefficient in combat, but a claw that grabs a creature can quickly take it out of action.
flavor: Scorpion Ship bears well-made craftsmanship—rigging tidy, timbers sound, and the scent of old leather of tar, rope, and long voyages.

name: Scourge of Shadow
entries: Reliable in a pinch, the scourge of shadow its weight and balance make it trustworthy in battle.
item_description: Reliable in a pinch, the scourge of shadow its weight and balance make it trustworthy in battle.
flavor: Scourge of Shadow is a nigh-mythic melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show nicks and polish; up close there’s a tang of metal and a quiet creak when drawn.

name: Scribe's Pen
reqAttune: by a creature with the Mark of Scribing
entries: You can use this pen to write on any surface. You decide whether the writing is visible or {@condition invisible}, but the writing is always visible to a person with the Mark of Scribing.
Any creature with the Mark of Scribing can use an action to touch the {@condition invisible} writing, making it visible to all.
If you use the pen to write on a creature that isn't a construct, the writing fades after 7 days.
attunementText: requires attunement by a creature with the Mark of Scribing
item_description: You can use this pen to write on any surface. You decide whether the writing is visible or {@condition invisible}, but the writing is always visible to a person with the Mark of Scribing.
flavor: Scribe's Pen looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with tool-marks and a whiff of parchment that speaks of use.

name: Scroll of Protection from Aberrations
entries: Using an action to read the scroll encloses you in an {@condition invisible} barrier that extends from you to form a 5-foot-radius, 10-foot-high cylinder. For 5 minutes, this barrier prevents aberrations from entering or affecting anything within the cylinder. The cylinder moves with you and remains centered on you. However, if you move in such a way that an aberration would be inside the cylinder, the effect ends. A creature can attempt to overcome the barrier by using an action to make a {@dc 15} Charisma check. On a success, the creature ceases to be affected by the barrier.

name: Scroll of Tarrasque Summoning
entries: Using an action to read the scroll causes the {@creature tarrasque} (see the creature's entry in the Monster Manual) to appear in an unoccupied space you can see within 1 mile of you. The tarrasque disappears when it drops to 0 hit points and is hostile toward all creatures other than itself.

name: Scroll of the Comet
entries: Inscribed in tidy hands, the scroll of the comet carries power for those who can read it.
item_description: Inscribed in tidy hands, the scroll of the comet carries power for those who can read it.
flavor: Scroll of the Comet carries crisp sigils and the dryness of vellum; a low hum rises when traced, and a tang of metal clings to the arcane ink.

name: Scroll of Titan Summoning (Animal Lord)
entries: When you take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to read this scroll, an {@creature Animal Lord|XMM} appears in an unoccupied space on the ground or in water that you can see within 1 mile of yourself.

The {@creature Animal Lord|XMM} is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures and disappears when it drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. If the {@creature Animal Lord|XMM} is summoned into a space that isn't large enough to contain it, the summoning fails, and the scroll is wasted.

entries: When you take a {@action Magic|XPHB} action to read this scroll, an {@creature Elemental Cataclysm|XMM} appears in an unoccupied space on the ground or in water that you can see within 1 mile of yourself.

The {@creature Elemental Cataclysm|XMM} is {@variantrule Hostile [Attitude]|XPHB|Hostile} toward all other creatures and disappears when it drops to 0 {@variantrule Hit Points|XPHB}. If the {@creature Elemental Cataclysm|XMM} is summoned into a space that isn't large enough to contain it, the summoning fails, and the scroll is wasted.

entries: The secondhand steal trinket smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.

name: Seeker Dart
entries: Reliable in a pinch, the seeker dart a straightforward design that trades flourish for grit.
item_description: Reliable in a pinch, the seeker dart a straightforward design that trades flourish for grit.
flavor: Seeker Dart is a notable ranged weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show tool-marks; up close there’s a dust of old vaults and a dull thrum when drawn.

name: Sekolahian Worshiping Statuette
entries: Skillfully carved from sandstone, this 1-foot-tall statuette depicts a shark twisting through the water with its mouth open. If any Tiny sea-dwelling animal is within 1 inch of the statuette's mouth, the shark flashes to life and deals 1 piercing damage to it. The shark can deal damage in this way no more than once per hour.
item_description: Skillfully carved from sandstone, this 1-foot-tall statuette depicts a shark twisting through the water with its mouth open. If any Tiny sea-dwelling animal is within 1 inch of the statuette's mouth, the shark flashes to life and deals 1 piercing damage to it. The shark can deal damage in this way no more than once per hour.
flavor: Sekolahian Worshiping Statuette looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with tool-marks and a smell of oil that speaks of use.

name: Selesnya Guild Signet
entries: Rumor runs that the selesnya guild signet remembers every hand that held it.
item_description: Rumor runs that the selesnya guild signet remembers every hand that held it.
flavor: Selesnya Guild Signet bears a finely crafted aura—cool to the touch, edges crisp, and a low hum of latent sorcery beneath the smell of oil.

name: Selesnya Keyrune
reqAttune: by a member of the Selesnya guild
entries: Carved from white and green marble in the shape of a wolf's head, this keyrune transforms into a {@creature dire wolf}. The wolf persists for 8 hours. Its Intelligence is 6, and it understands Elvish and Sylvan but can't speak those languages. While it is within 1 mile of you, you can communicate with each other telepathically.

When you use an action to speak the item's command word and place the keyrune on the ground in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you, the keyrune transforms into a {@creature dire wolf}. If there isn't enough space for the creature, the keyrune doesn't transform.

The creature is friendly to you, your companions, and other members of your guild (unless those guild members are hostile to you). It understands your languages and obeys your spoken commands. If you issue no commands, the creature takes the {@action Dodge} action and moves to avoid danger.

At the end of the duration, the creature reverts to its keyrune form. It reverts early if it drops to 0 hit points or if you use an action to speak the command word again while touching it. When the creature reverts to its keyrune form, it can't transform again until 36 hours have passed.
attunementText: requires attunement by a member of the Selesnya guild
item_description: Carved from white and green marble in the shape of a wolf's head, this keyrune transforms into a {@creature dire wolf}. The wolf persists for 8 hours. Its Intelligence is 6, and it understands Elvish and Sylvan but can't speak those languages. While it is within 1 mile of you, you can communicate with each other telepathically.
flavor: Selesnya Keyrune looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with careful repairs and a hint of ozone that speaks of use.

name: Semiautomatic Pistol
item_description: Crafted in old guild halls, the semiautomatic pistol a straightforward design that trades flourish for grit.
entries: Crafted in old guild halls, the semiautomatic pistol a straightforward design that trades flourish for grit.
flavor: Semiautomatic Pistol is a serviceable ranged weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show nicks and polish; up close there’s a smell of oil and a quiet creak when drawn.

name: Sending Stone
entries: Also at rank 1, you are given use of an Acquisitions Incorporated sending stone, an uncommon magic item that resembles a gemstone in a bold setting. It functions like a normal sending stone, except that it has no matching stone and allows communication with Head Office, specific secretarians you know, and the secretarian nearest your location. You must succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check to establish contact. Once the stone is successfully used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.
Making contact with another secretarian assumes that they are in possession of their own sending stone.

entries.caption: Quirks of Your Sending Stone
rows: It's a flip stone.
It gets great reception everywhere except in your headquarters.
It sometimes picks up other magical conversations.
It's the perfect size, shape, and weight to be used as a skipping stone.
It heats up when you use it, to the extent that it once burned through your gloves.
It has an obnoxious ringtone that you can't work out how to change.
It fails to notify you of incoming messages except for a faint pulsating glow.
It's voice activated, so that every time you talk to someone, it tries to send a message to someone else.

entries.name: Rumor Mill
entries: Also at rank 2, whenever your franchise begins a major quest or mission, make a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill History}) check. On a success, you can learn up to three rumors related to creatures or organizations involved in the mission, which come to you through your sending stone. These rumors reflect current or historical knowledge possessed by Acquisitions Incorporated or the organization's many contacts.

entries.name: Improved Rumor Mill
entries: At rank 3, when you use your Rumor Mill feature, the DM provides you with a sense of which parts of a particular rumor are inaccurate, if any. You do not necessarily learn the truth behind those false rumors.

item_description: Also at rank 1, you are given use of an Acquisitions Incorporated sending stone, an uncommon magic item that resembles a gemstone in a bold setting. It functions like a normal sending stone, except that it has no matching stone and allows communication with Head Office, specific secretarians you know, and the secretarian nearest your location. You must succeed on a {@dc 15} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check to establish contact. Once the stone is successfully used, it can't be used again until the next dawn.
flavor: Sending Stone looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with nicks and polish and a dust of old vaults that speaks of use.

name: Sending Stones
entries: Sending Stones come in pairs, with each stone carved to match the other so the pairing is easily recognized. While you touch one stone, you can cast {@spell Sending|XPHB} from it. The target is the bearer of the other stone. If no creature bears the other stone, you know that fact as soon as you use the stone, and you don't cast the spell.
Once Sending is cast using either stone, the stones can't be used again until the next dawn. If one of the stones in a pair is destroyed, the other one becomes nonmagical.
item_description: Sending Stones come in pairs, with each stone carved to match the other so the pairing is easily recognized. While you touch one stone, you can cast {@spell Sending|XPHB} from it. The target is the bearer of the other stone. If no creature bears the other stone, you know that fact as soon as you use the stone, and you don't cast the spell.
flavor: Sending Stones looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with well-worn grips and a whiff of parchment that speaks of use.

name: Serpent Scale Armor
entries: This suit of magic armor is made from shimmering scales. While wearing it, you can apply your full Dexterity modifier (instead of a maximum of +2) when determining your Armor Class. In addition, this armor does not impose disadvantage on your Dexterity ({@skill Stealth}) checks.

flavor: Serpent Scale Armor is a notable suit of metal and leather—buckles and rivets tight, plates and links bearing well-worn grips; it carries the scent of old leather of long marches.

name: Shiftweave
entries: When a suit of shiftweave is created, up to five different outfits can be embedded into the cloth. While wearing the clothing, you can speak its command word as a bonus action to transform your outfit into your choice of one of the other designs contained within it. Regardless of its appearance, the outfit can't be anything but clothing. Although it can duplicate the look of other magical clothing, it doesn't gain their magical properties.

name: Shrike Ship
entries: This swift vessel is a relatively recent design, quickly gaining popularity with merchants and pirates. A shrike ship's legs enable it to land safely on the ground. The ship can float but isn't built for traveling on water and sinks quickly in rough seas.

Standard weaponry on a shrike ship includes three ballistae—one on the forecastle, one in the middle of the top deck, and one on the sterncastle. In a desperate situation, the ship's reinforced bow can be used as a piercing ram.
item_description: This swift vessel is a relatively recent design, quickly gaining popularity with merchants and pirates. A shrike ship's legs enable it to land safely on the ground. The ship can float but isn't built for traveling on water and sinks quickly in rough seas.
flavor: Shrike Ship bears serviceable craftsmanship—rigging tidy, timbers sound, and the smell of oil of tar, rope, and long voyages.

The saving throw DC for the weapon's poison increases to 15.

While holding the rapier, you can use an action to cast one of the following spells from it (save {@dc 15}): {@spell cloudkill}, {@spell darkness}, {@spell levitate}, or {@spell web}. Once a spell has been cast using the rapier, that spell can't be cast from the rapier again until the next dawn.

The saving throw DC for the weapon's poison and spells cast from the weapon increases to 17.

name: Silver (sp)
entries: Common coins come in several different denominations based on the relative worth of the metal from which they are made. The three most common coins are the gold piece (gp), the silver piece (sp), and the copper piece (cp).

With one gold piece, a character can buy a belt pouch, 50 feet of good rope, or a goat. A skilled (but not exceptional) artisan can earn one gold piece a day. The gold piece is the standard unit of measure for wealth, even if the coin itself is not commonly used. When merchants discuss deals that involve goods or services worth hundreds or thousands of gold pieces, the transactions don't usually involve the exchange of individual coins. Rather, the gold piece is a standard measure of value, and the actual exchange is in gold bars, letters of credit, or valuable goods.
One gold piece is worth ten silver pieces, the most prevalent coin among commoners. A silver piece buys a laborer's work for a day, a flask of lamp oil, or a night's rest in a poor inn.
One silver piece is worth ten copper pieces, which are common among laborers and beggars. A single copper piece buys a candle, a torch, or a piece of chalk.

In addition, unusual coins made of other precious metals sometimes appear in treasure hoards. The electrum piece (ep) and the platinum piece (pp) originate from fallen empires and lost kingdoms, and they sometimes arouse suspicion and skepticism when used in transactions. An electrum piece is worth five silver pieces, and a platinum piece is worth ten gold pieces.
A standard coin weighs about a third of an ounce, so fifty coins weigh a pound.
item_description: Common coins come in several different denominations based on the relative worth of the metal from which they are made. The three most common coins are the gold piece (gp), the silver piece (sp), and the copper piece (cp).
flavor: Silver (sp) is standard stock—sealed, weighed, and marked for barter; the smell of oil hints at its origin.

name: Silverquill Trinket
entries: When you make your character, you may roll once on the Silverquill Trinkets table, instead of on the {@item trinket|phb|Trinkets table} in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, for your starting trinket.

entries.caption: Silverquill Trinkets
rows: A black leather notebook filled with half-finished poems
A set of flashcards detailing different colloquialisms and their meanings
A canteen that makes any liquid drunk from it taste sweet
A forged permission slip granting access to the special archives of Strixhaven's libraries
A stylish silver pin that references a famous series of novels about warlocks
A stack of small pieces of parchment, each enchanted to stick to whatever surface it's pressed against and peel off easily

item_description: When you make your character, you may roll once on the Silverquill Trinkets table, instead of on the {@item trinket|phb|Trinkets table} in the {@book Player's Handbook|PHB}, for your starting trinket.

entries: Rumor runs that the simic guild signet remembers every hand that held it.
item_description: Rumor runs that the simic guild signet remembers every hand that held it.
flavor: Simic Guild Signet bears a notable aura—cool to the touch, edges crisp, and a soft chime of latent sorcery beneath the whiff of parchment.

name: Simic Keyrune
reqAttune: by a member of the Simic guild
entries: This keyrune is assembled from coral, mother-of-pearl, and chrome and adorned with the spirals and curves characteristic of Simic ornamentation. The head resembles the shell of a sea creature. On command, the keyrune turns into a {@creature category 1 krasis|GGR} that has the Grabber and Stabilizing Legs adaptations. The transformation lasts for up to 5 hours.

When you use an action to speak the item's command word and place the keyrune on the ground in an unoccupied space within 5 feet of you, the keyrune transforms into a {@creature category 1 krasis|GGR} that has the Grabber and Stabilizing Legs adaptations. If there isn't enough space for the creature, the keyrune doesn't transform.

The creature is friendly to you, your companions, and other members of your guild (unless those guild members are hostile to you). It understands your languages and obeys your spoken commands. If you issue no commands, the creature takes the {@action Dodge} action and moves to avoid danger.

At the end of the duration, the creature reverts to its keyrune form. It reverts early if it drops to 0 hit points or if you use an action to speak the command word again while touching it. When the creature reverts to its keyrune form, it can't transform again until 36 hours have passed.
attunementText: requires attunement by a member of the Simic guild

name: Skull Helm
entries: While wearing this skull-shaped helm, you have resistance to cold, poison, and necrotic damage.

Additionally, while wearing the helm, you can cast {@spell Spirit of Death|BMT} from it without requiring material components. Once you use the helm to cast the spell, the helm can't cast this spell again until the next dawn.
item_description: While wearing this skull-shaped helm, you have resistance to cold, poison, and necrotic damage.
flavor: Skull Helm (Helm) bears a masterwork aura—cool to the touch, edges crisp, and a dull thrum of latent sorcery beneath the dust of old vaults.

name: Skull of Selfish Knowledge
entries: You may use an action to make the magical skull devour a nonmagical book, map, or scroll. Once devoured the learning is forever available to you, but you can never write the information down or communicate it to others. It is for you alone.
item_description: You may use an action to make the magical skull devour a nonmagical book, map, or scroll. Once devoured the learning is forever available to you, but you can never write the information down or communicate it to others. It is for you alone.

name: Skyblinder Staff
entries: The skyblinder staff is smooth to the touch, a channel for practiced magic.
item_description: The skyblinder staff is smooth to the touch, a channel for practiced magic.
flavor: Skyblinder Staff looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with scuffs at the edges and a smell of oil that speaks of use.

name: Skysail
entries: These bat-like wings were first used by the {@book Air Ashari|TDCSR|3|Zephrah} to soar through the sky. They are constructed of either leather and bone, or cloth and wood, and are set onto a sturdy wooden pole that helps their user remain stable during flight.

While these wings are open and you are riding the skysail, you can glide through the air. You have a flying speed of 60 feet, but you must descend at least 10 feet by the end of each of your turns and you can't gain altitude.
Additionally, while in contact with the skysail, you can use an action to cast the {@spell fly} spell on yourself, with a duration of 1 minute and requiring no {@status concentration}.

The spell ends if you lose physical contact with the skysail. Once this property is used, it can't be used again until the next dawn, or unless the skysail is immersed in powerful magic of elemental air. (This includes magic such as that found at the top of the {@book Summit Peaks|TDCSR|3|Summit Peaks} near the rift of air in {@book Zephrah|TDCSR|3|Zephrah}, or on the Elemental Plane of Air).
When the skysail is not in use, its wings can be retracted, and its pole can be used as a {@item quarterstaff|PHB}.
item_description: These bat-like wings were first used by the {@book Air Ashari|TDCSR|3|Zephrah} to soar through the sky. They are constructed of either leather and bone, or cloth and wood, and are set onto a sturdy wooden pole that helps their user remain stable during flight.
flavor: Skysail is a sigiled melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show well-worn grips; up close there’s a tang of metal and a faint susurrus when drawn.

Sled dogs must take a short rest after pulling a sled for 1 hour; otherwise, they gain one level of {@condition exhaustion}.

flavor: Sleep Grenade is compact and deadly—casings snug, fuses trimmed, and a smell of oil that warns of volatile charge.

item_description: Made for wandering heroes, the sling its edge holds well with a bit of care and whetstone.
entries: Made for wandering heroes, the sling its edge holds well with a bit of care and whetstone.
flavor: Sling is a workmanlike ranged weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show tool-marks; up close there’s a dust of old vaults and a soft chime when drawn.

name: Sling Bullet
entries: Sling bullets are used with a weapon that has the ammunition property to make a ranged attack. Each time you attack with the weapon, you expend one piece of ammunition. Drawing the ammunition from a quiver, case, or other container is part of the attack (you need a free hand to load a one-handed weapon). At the end of the battle, you can recover half your expended ammunition by taking a minute to search the battlefield.
Sling Bullets are typically stored in a {@item Pouch|XPHB} (bought separately).

entries: Simple yet dependable, the sling of giant felling it rides easy on the hip and comes free without fuss.
item_description: Simple yet dependable, the sling of giant felling it rides easy on the hip and comes free without fuss.
flavor: Sling of Giant Felling is a sturdy ranged weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show well-worn grips; up close there’s a scent of old leather and a quiet creak when drawn.

name: Slippers of Spider Climbing
entries: While you wear these light shoes, you can move up, down, and across vertical surfaces and along ceilings, while leaving your hands free. You have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}. However, the slippers don't allow you to move this way on a slippery surface, such as one covered by ice or oil.

You have a {@variantrule Climb Speed|XPHB} equal to your {@variantrule Speed|XPHB}. However, the slippers don't allow you to move this way on a slippery surface, such as one covered by ice or oil.

name: Slumbering Dragon Vessel
entries: This vessel can be a potion bottle, drinking horn, or other container meant to hold a liquid.

As a bonus action, if the vessel is empty, you can speak the command word to fill the vessel with one of the following (your choice): ale, olive oil, a {@item potion of healing}, or a {@item potion of climbing}. Once this property is used, it can't be used until the next dawn. A potion you create in this way loses its magical properties if it isn't imbibed within 24 hours.
item_description: This vessel can be a potion bottle, drinking horn, or other container meant to hold a liquid.
flavor: Slumbering Dragon Vessel looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with well-worn grips and a scent of old leather that speaks of use.

name: Slumbering Dragon-Touched Focus
entries: This wondrous item can be a scepter, an orb, an amulet, a crystal, or another finely crafted object. It typically incorporates imagery of dragons' wings, claws, teeth, or scales.
You have advantage on initiative rolls. While you are holding the focus, it can function as a spellcasting focus for all your spells.
item_description: This wondrous item can be a scepter, an orb, an amulet, a crystal, or another finely crafted object. It typically incorporates imagery of dragons' wings, claws, teeth, or scales.
flavor: Slumbering Dragon-Touched Focus looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with tool-marks and a dust of old vaults that speaks of use.

name: Slumbering Scaled Ornament
entries: This ornament can be jewelry, a cloak, or another wearable accessory. It appears to be fashioned from a dragon's scale, tooth, or claw, or it incorporates images in those shapes.
You have advantage on saving throws you make to avoid being {@condition charmed} or {@condition frightened} or to end those conditions on you.

name: Smith's Tools
additionalEntries: Smith's tools allow you to work metal, heating it to alter its shape, repair damage, or work raw ingots into useful items.

additionalEntries.name: Components
entries: Smith's tools include hammers, tongs, charcoal, rags, and a whetstone.

additionalEntries.name: Arcana and History
entries: Your expertise lends you additional insight when examining metal objects, such as weapons.

additionalEntries.name: Investigation
entries: You can spot clues and make deductions that others might overlook when an investigation involves armor, weapons, or other metalwork.

additionalEntries.name: Repair
entries: With access to your tools and an open flame hot enough to make metal pliable, you can restore 10 hit points to a damaged metal object for each hour of work.

additionalEntries.caption: Smith's Tools
rows: Sharpen a dull blade
Repair a suit of armor
Sunder a nonmagical metal object

items.name: Ability:
entries: Strength

items.name: Utilize:
entries: Pry open a door or container ({@dc 20})

items.name: Craft:
entries: Any Melee weapon (except {@item Club|XPHB}, {@item Greatclub|XPHB}, {@item Quarterstaff|XPHB}, and {@item Whip|XPHB}), Medium armor (except {@item Hide Armor|XPHB|Hide}), Heavy armor, {@item Ball Bearings|XPHB}, {@item Bucket|XPHB}, {@item Caltrops|XPHB}, {@item Chain|XPHB}, {@item Crowbar|XPHB}, {@item Firearm Bullets (10)|XPHB|Firearm Bullets}, {@item Grappling Hook|XPHB}, {@item Iron Pot|XPHB}, {@item Iron Spikes|XPHB}, {@item Sling Bullets (20)|XPHB|Sling Bullets}

item_description: Strength
flavor: Smith's Tools is a well-made kit—well-fitted pieces with careful repairs, hinges and clasps snug, and the honest dust of old vaults of work.

name: Smoke Grenade
entries: {#itemEntry Grenade|XDMG}

The area of the {@variantrule Sphere [Area of Effect]|XPHB|Sphere} is {@variantrule Heavily Obscured|XPHB} by smoke for 1 minute. A strong wind (such as the {@spell Gust of Wind|XPHB} spell) disperses the smoke.
item_description: {#itemEntry Grenade|XDMG}
flavor: Smoke Grenade is compact and deadly—casings snug, fuses trimmed, and a smell of oil that warns of volatile charge.

name: Smokepowder
entries: The smokepowder rugged enough for damp caves and busy market streets.
item_description: The smokepowder rugged enough for damp caves and busy market streets.
flavor: Smokepowder looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with scuffs at the edges and a hint of ozone that speaks of use.

name: Snicker-Snack
entries: Forged for perilous roads, the snicker-snack it rides easy on the hip and comes free without fuss.
attunementText: requires attunement by a non-evil creature
item_description: Forged for perilous roads, the snicker-snack it rides easy on the hip and comes free without fuss.
flavor: Snicker-Snack is a legend-haunted melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show tool-marks; up close there’s a whiff of parchment and a soft chime when drawn.

name: Snowshoes
entries: Snowshoes reduce the likelihood of their wearer getting stuck in the deep snow.
item_description: Snowshoes reduce the likelihood of their wearer getting stuck in the deep snow.
flavor: Snowshoes is serviceable field kit: straps tight, stitching true, and the scent of old leather that clings to road-beaten gear.

name: Soap
item_description: The soap smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
entries: The soap smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
flavor: Soap is well-made field kit: straps tight, stitching true, and the scent of old leather that clings to road-beaten gear.

name: Songhorn
entries: A recorder, a simple type of flute, usually carved from wood.
item_description: A recorder, a simple type of flute, usually carved from wood.
flavor: Songhorn is a serviceable instrument—grain smooth under the fingers, fittings bright, and the lingering tang of metal of performance.

name: Soothsalts
entries: The soothsalts smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
item_description: The soothsalts smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
flavor: Soothsalts is plain field kit: straps tight, stitching true, and the scent of old leather that clings to road-beaten gear.

name: Sorcerous Spyglass
entries: This elegant brass {@item spyglass|phb} features an intricate lens mechanism. A creature looking through the sorcerous spyglass has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks to detect things that can be seen. In addition, the user can view magical auras while looking through the spyglass, as if under the effect of a {@spell detect magic} spell.
item_description: This elegant brass {@item spyglass|phb} features an intricate lens mechanism. A creature looking through the sorcerous spyglass has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks to detect things that can be seen. In addition, the user can view magical auras while looking through the spyglass, as if under the effect of a {@spell detect magic} spell.
flavor: Sorcerous Spyglass looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with scuffs at the edges and a hint of ozone that speaks of use.

name: Soul Bag
entries: When an evil humanoid dies as a result of a {@creature night hag}'s Nightmare Haunting, the hag catches the soul in this black sack made of stitched flesh. A soul bag can hold only one evil soul at a time, and only the night hag who crafted the bag can catch a soul with it. Crafting a soul bag takes 7 days and a humanoid sacrifice (whose flesh is used to make the bag).
item_description: When an evil humanoid dies as a result of a {@creature night hag}'s Nightmare Haunting, the hag catches the soul in this black sack made of stitched flesh. A soul bag can hold only one evil soul at a time, and only the night hag who crafted the bag can catch a soul with it. Crafting a soul bag takes 7 days and a humanoid sacrifice (whose flesh is used to make the bag).
flavor: Soul Bag (Bag) bears a spellwrought aura—cool to the touch, edges crisp, and a quiet creak of latent sorcery beneath the hint of ozone.

name: Soul Coin
entries: The soul coin smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
item_description: The soul coin smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
flavor: Soul Coin looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with well-worn grips and a dust of old vaults that speaks of use.

name: Sovereign Glue
entries: The sovereign glue smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
item_description: The sovereign glue smells faintly of leather and lamp oil.
flavor: Sovereign Glue looks true to its purpose—well-kept, with tool-marks and a dust of old vaults that speaks of use.

name: Space Galleon
entries: The space galleon is a mainstay among the host of vessels that ply Wildspace and the Astral Sea. Space galleons can easily pass for ordinary seafaring galleons. Because they can land on water and move across it like their namesakes, they can sail into ports on terrestrial worlds without attracting undue attention. Like an ordinary galleon, a space galleon isn't built to land on the ground (its keel would cause it to roll on its side). The ship's standard weaponry includes two forward-mounted ballistae and an aft-mounted mangonel.
item_description: The space galleon is a mainstay among the host of vessels that ply Wildspace and the Astral Sea. Space galleons can easily pass for ordinary seafaring galleons. Because they can land on water and move across it like their namesakes, they can sail into ports on terrestrial worlds without attracting undue attention. Like an ordinary galleon, a space galleon isn't built to land on the ground (its keel would cause it to roll on its side). The ship's standard weaponry includes two forward-mounted ballistae and an aft-mounted mangonel.
flavor: Space Galleon bears plain craftsmanship—rigging tidy, timbers sound, and the smell of oil of tar, rope, and long voyages.

name: Spaceship Trinket
entries: The Spaceship Trinkets table below offers a selection of trinkets appropriate for adventures with sci-fi themes. The adventure includes encounters that ask you to roll on the table to determine what random trinkets the characters find in certain locations on the spaceship. None of the trinkets requires an energy cell.

entries.caption: Spaceship Trinkets
rows: Disembodied robot arm with a mind of its own
Wearable blanket with sleeves and a hood
Small, rectangular device that can record and play back audio of up to 1 minute in length
Glow-in-the-dark ink pen
Fashionable jumpsuit
Compact scanner that reports whether an object is recyclable in a cheery tone
Wristwatch programmed to beep at a specific time
Handheld cylinder that produces a 15-foot cone of bright light for up to 1 hour every 24 hours
Colorful toy ray gun with lights and sounds
Bottle of fizzy, sweet-tasting liquid
Map of an unexplored star system
Motorized toothbrush that might have been used
Tiny robot that shines boots and shoes

Pressurized red canister with a flexible hose that, when squeezed as an action, sprays a 15-foot cone of foam. The foam extinguishes all nonmagical flames in the cone. The canister can perform this action only once.
Loaf of space bread covered in blue-green mold
Handheld screen that plays a children's story about a friendly, three-eyed frog named Swampy
Compact device that displays the current weather
Empty metal bottle that maintains the temperature of liquids stored in it for {@dice 1d4} hours
Tiny disc that emits a high-pitched noise in the presence of smoke or mild cooking fumes
Aerosolized can of metal polish
Identification badge of a deceased crew member
Depleted energy cell
Pocket-sized instrument that clicks rapidly within 10 feet of radiation (see the "{@area Spaceship Features|4ae|x}" section later in this adventure)
Vacuum-sealed package of shriveled frankfurters
Tin hat that telepathically broadcasts the wearer's surface thoughts to creatures within 10 feet of it
Chalky moon rock
Collar that, when placed on a Medium or smaller Beast, translates its cries into Common
Bottle of expired medicine for treating dizziness
Tiny speaker that plays a catchy tune in an unknown language
Handheld tool for removing bolts and screws
Cautionary pamphlet about the dangers of space
Miniature flying saucer
Tiny, animatronic bunny that hops after the creature that activates it
Stick of deodorant with a surprising scent
Countertop appliance that can transform any fruit into a pulpy juice
Glass pendant filled with stardust
Pot containing an artificially dwarfed tree
Otherworldly insect preserved in amber
Syringe filled with a viscous, yellow serum
Tiny brass orrery
Log of passenger names
Gas mask with a hole in it
Small glass terrarium with an empty cocoon
Dongle that never plugs in correctly on the first try
Holster fashioned from an unknown reptile's hide
Severed bundle of important-looking wires
Prosthetic limb with magnetic attachments
Set of polyhedral dice that buzz and flash when they land on their highest result
Musical instrument that plays electronic tones
Trading card of a beloved fictional hero from a far-off world

item_description: The Spaceship Trinkets table below offers a selection of trinkets appropriate for adventures with sci-fi themes. The adventure includes encounters that ask you to roll on the table to determine what random trinkets the characters find in certain locations on the spaceship. None of the trinkets requires an energy cell.
flavor: Spaceship Trinket is well-made field kit: straps tight, stitching true, and the tang of metal that clings to road-beaten gear.

name: Speaking Stone
entries: The key to long-distance, virtually instantaneous communication across Khorvaire is House Sivis's network of message stations. Each station contains at least one speaking stone, which is carved from a Siberys dragonshard and inscribed with arcane symbols that uniquely identify it. If you're a gnome with the Mark of Scribing, you can touch the stone and use an action to cast the {@spell sending} spell from it. The target is any other speaking stone whose location or unique sequence of symbols you know. A creature within 5 feet of the stone hears the message as if they were the target.
In a Sivis message station, a gnome is always on duty by the speaking stone, listening for messages that might come in and transcribing them for delivery to their intended recipients.

name: Spear of Backbiting
entries: Simple yet dependable, the spear of backbiting nicks and oil stains speak to many a fray.
item_description: Simple yet dependable, the spear of backbiting nicks and oil stains speak to many a fray.
flavor: Spear of Backbiting is a exceptional melee weapon—balanced in the hand, its surfaces show nicks and polish; up close there’s a whiff of parchment and a dull thrum when drawn.

name: Spell Bottle
entries: This glass bottle can store one spell of up to 5th level at a time. When found, roll a {@dice d6} and subtract 1; the total determines the level of spell in the bottle (the DM chooses the spell, and 0 means the bottle is empty). A swirling blue vapor fills the bottle while it contains a spell.
When the bottle is empty, any creature can cast a spell of 1st through 5th level into it by touching it while casting. The spell has no effect other than to be stored in the bottle.

While holding the bottle, you can cast the spell stored in it. The spell uses the slot level, spell save DC, spell attack bonus, and spellcasting ability of the original caster, but is otherwise treated as if you cast the spell. The bottle becomes empty once the spell is cast.

If you're holding the empty bottle when you see a creature casting a spell within 60 feet of you, you can open the bottle as a reaction in an attempt to interrupt the spell. If the creature is casting a spell of 3rd level or lower, the spell has no effect, and it is stored in the bottle. If it is casting a spell of 4th level or higher, make an Intelligence check. The DC equals 10 + the spell's level. On a success, the spell has no effect, and it is stored in the bottle.
item_description: This glass bottle can store one spell of up to 5th level at a time. When found, roll a {@dice d6} and subtract 1; the total determines the level of spell in the bottle (the DM chooses the spell, and 0 means the bottle is empty). A swirling blue vapor fills the bottle while it contains a spell.

name: Spell Scroll (1st Level)
entries: A spell scroll bears the words of a single spell, written as a mystical cipher. If the spell is on your class's spell list, you can read the scroll and cast its spell without providing any material components. Otherwise, the scroll is unintelligible. Casting the spell by reading the scroll requires the spell's normal casting time. Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and it crumbles to dust. If the casting is interrupted, the scroll is not lost.

If the spell is on your class's spell list but of a higher level than you can normally cast, you must make an ability check using your spellcasting ability to determine whether you cast it successfully. The DC is 11. On a failed check, the spell disappears from the scroll with no other effect.
Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and the scroll itself crumbles to dust.
A spell cast from this scroll has a save DC of 13 and an attack bonus of {@hit 5}.

A wizard spell on a spell scroll can be copied just as spells in spellbooks can be copied. When a spell is copied from a spell scroll, the copier must succeed on a {@dc 11} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check. If the check succeeds, the spell is successfully copied. Whether the check succeeds or fails, the spell scroll is destroyed.
item_description: A spell scroll bears the words of a single spell, written as a mystical cipher. If the spell is on your class's spell list, you can read the scroll and cast its spell without providing any material components. Otherwise, the scroll is unintelligible. Casting the spell by reading the scroll requires the spell's normal casting time. Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and it crumbles to dust. If the casting is interrupted, the scroll is not lost.
flavor: Spell Scroll (1st Level) carries crisp sigils and the dryness of vellum; a quiet creak rises when traced, and a scent of old leather clings to the arcane ink.

flavor: Spell Scroll (7th Level) carries crisp sigils and the dryness of vellum; a dull thrum rises when traced, and a scent of old leather clings to the arcane ink.

name: Spell Scroll (8th Level)
entries: A spell scroll bears the words of a single spell, written as a mystical cipher. If the spell is on your class's spell list, you can read the scroll and cast its spell without providing any material components. Otherwise, the scroll is unintelligible. Casting the spell by reading the scroll requires the spell's normal casting time. Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and it crumbles to dust. If the casting is interrupted, the scroll is not lost.

If the spell is on your class's spell list but of a higher level than you can normally cast, you must make an ability check using your spellcasting ability to determine whether you cast it successfully. The DC is 18. On a failed check, the spell disappears from the scroll with no other effect.
Once the spell is cast, the words on the scroll fade, and the scroll itself crumbles to dust.
A spell cast from this scroll has a save DC of 18 and an attack bonus of {@hit 10}.

A wizard spell on a spell scroll can be copied just as spells in spellbooks can be copied. When a spell is copied from a spell scroll, the copier must succeed on a {@dc 18} Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check. If the check succeeds, the spell is successfully copied. Whether the check succeeds or fails, the spell scroll is destroyed.
